experiment.statistical_test: Chi-squared test for proportion of vanishing GW invariants vs. null expectation (40% baseline from generic h¹¹=17 polytopes without D₆ symmetry); alpha=0.05. Matrix rank determined algebraically (exact computation, no statistical test needed).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: 20 percentage point difference in vanishing rate (60% vs. 40% null); rank deficit of 1 in 3×3 Yukawa matrix is binary (rank 2 vs. rank 3).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: At degree ≤ 5 with h¹¹=17, expect O(10²-10³) curve classes in Mori cone. With n=200 classes, chi-squared test at alpha=0.05 has >99% power to detect 20pp difference (60% vs. 40%). Computation is deterministic once triangulation is fixed; main uncertainty is from triangulation choice, mitigated by sampling multiple D₆-compatible triangulations.
limitations: Mirror symmetry computation of GW invariants requires finding the mirror CY, which may not have closed-form periods for all moduli directions.
Higher-genus GW invariants (g ≥ 1) are not addressed; these could modify Yukawa structure at loop level.
Discrete torsion effects in orbifold quotients are not incorporated; F-theory uplift may introduce additional selection rules.
Comparison to observed mass hierarchies is qualitative without specifying the full moduli stabilization and Kähler potential.

hypotheses.source_question: How do discrete symmetry groups (particularly D₆) of Calabi-Yau threefolds constructed from reflexive polytopes persist or break under deformation from Fano to quasi-Fano geometry, and what are the implications for flavor symmetry preservation in string compactifications?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the D₆ discrete symmetry of the GL=12 Calabi-Yau threefold is preserved under ambient toric variety deformations from Fano to quasi-Fano precisely when the quasi-Fano singularities lie outside the CY hypersurface, and this preservation directly determines whether the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings remain selection-rule protected.
hypotheses.mechanism: The D₆ automorphism group of the GL=12 reflexive polytope lifts to the ambient toric variety and restricts to the CY hypersurface. When the ambient variety degenerates from Fano to quasi-Fano, new singularities appear at toric fixed points. If these singularities intersect the generic CY hypersurface, the automorphism group acting on the smooth CY is reduced (D₆ → proper subgroup); if the singularities miss the hypersurface, D₆ survives intact. The causal direction is: ambient geometry singularity locus → CY automorphism group → Yukawa selection rules, not the reverse.
hypotheses.prediction: For the GL=12 polytope, at least 80% of D₆ generators will survive when quasi-Fano singularities do not intersect the CY hypersurface (measured via induced automorphism on H²,¹), while at least one generator will be broken (reducing |Aut| by factor ≥2) when singularities do intersect. This will manifest as a reduction from 26 to ≤15 independent D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings in the broken case.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: The hypothesis is refuted if: (1) D₆ symmetry is fully preserved even when quasi-Fano singularities explicitly lie on the CY hypersurface (intersection computed via Stanley-Reisner ideal), OR (2) D₆ is broken even when singularities provably miss the hypersurface. Either outcome would show that singularity locus is not the controlling geometric feature for symmetry preservation.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Factor ≥2 change in |Aut(CY)| between Fano and quasi-Fano ambient cases where singularity intersection differs; equivalently, reduction from 26 to ≤15 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings (≥40% reduction) in the broken case.

experiment.approach: Systematically compute automorphism groups of CY hypersurfaces in the GL=12 polytope family under controlled Fano→quasi-Fano deformations, tracking which D₆ generators survive and correlating with singularity-hypersurface intersection.
steps: Use CyTools to load the GL=12 reflexive polytope and enumerate all triangulations giving smooth CY threefolds with the full D₆ polytope automorphism group.
Identify the toric divisors where quasi-Fano degenerations introduce singularities by computing the anticanonical divisor's failure of ampleness on each triangulation.

For each triangulation, compute the Stanley-Reisner ideal and determine whether quasi-Fano singular loci (codimension-2 or higher strata in the toric fan) intersect the generic CY hypersurface defined by the Newton polynomial.
Partition triangulations into two classes: (A) singularities miss CY hypersurface, (B) singularities intersect CY hypersurface.

For 10 representative triangulations from each class, explicitly compute the automorphism group of the CY hypersurface using the induced action on H^{1,1} and H^{2,1} via CyTools cohomology routines and SageMath group actions.
Count D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings via the triple intersection numbers ∫ J ∧ J ∧ J restricted to D₆-invariant divisor combinations in each case.
Statistical comparison: compute the mean |Aut(CY)| and number of D₆-invariant Yukawas for classes A vs B; test for significant difference using two-sided t-test.
experiment.estimated_effort: 3-4 weeks compute time on standard cluster (triangulation enumeration is the bottleneck for h¹¹=17)
experiment.data_requirements: GL=12 polytope from KS database; CyTools installation with triangulation capabilities; ~1000 CPU-hours for exhaustive triangulation enumeration, reducible to ~100 hours with sampling strategy.
experiment.expected_positive: Class A triangulations retain full D₆ with 26 invariant Yukawas; Class B triangulations show |Aut| reduced by factor ≥2 and invariant Yukawas ≤15. Two-sided t-test p < 0.01 for the difference in means.
experiment.expected_negative: No significant difference in |Aut| or Yukawa count between classes A and B (p > 0.10), or paradoxical pattern where singularity intersection correlates with symmetry enhancement rather than breaking.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The presence or absence of quasi-Fano singularity intersection with the CY hypersurface has no effect on the CY automorphism group order or the number of D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings (mean difference = 0).
experiment.statistical_test: Two-sided Welch's t-test for unequal variances, α = 0.01, comparing |Aut(CY)| and N_Yukawa between Class A and Class B triangulations; effect size reported as Cohen's d.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Cohen's d > 1.0 (large effect); with n=10 per class at 80% power and α=0.01, detectable mean difference of ~1.5 standard deviations in |Aut| or Yukawa count.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Assuming large effect (d=1.2) based on the discrete nature of symmetry breaking (factor ≥2 in group order), α=0.01, power=0.80, requires n≥8 per class. We sample n=10 per class for robustness. If triangulation space permits, increase to n=20 for d=0.8 detection.
limitations: Exhaustive triangulation enumeration may be computationally prohibitive for h¹¹=17; may require stratified sampling.
Automorphism computation relies on induced action on cohomology, which may miss 'hidden' automorphisms not visible at this level.
Quasi-Fano deformations within a single polytope may not span all phenomenologically relevant cases.
Physical Yukawa couplings involve instanton corrections not captured by classical intersection theory.
experiment.requires_followup: Full confirmation of Yukawa texture predictions requires explicit string amplitude calculation including E3-instanton contributions on del Pezzo divisors, which is beyond current automated computational tools and may require targeted analytic work.

hypotheses.source_question: How does the failure of very ampleness (versus birationally very ampleness) of divisor classes on the GL=12 D₆-symmetric Calabi-Yau threefold constrain or enhance the discrete symmetry action on Yukawa couplings?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that D₆-invariant divisor classes on the GL=12 Calabi-Yau threefold that fail very ampleness (but remain birationally very ample) cause a systematic reduction in the rank of the perturbative Yukawa matrix by introducing D₆-fixed exceptional loci whose twisted-sector contributions are selection-rule forbidden at tree level.
hypotheses.mechanism: When a D₆-invariant divisor D is birationally very ample but not very ample, the base locus B = Bs(|D|) is contracted under the rational map φ_D. If B contains D₆-fixed points or curves, the exceptional divisor E of the resolution π: X̃ → X carries non-trivial D₆ representations. Matter fields localized at E transform in twisted sectors whose Yukawa couplings ∫Ω∧ψᵢ∧ψⱼ∧ψₖ vanish unless the D₆ tensor product contains the trivial representation. This geometric obstruction causally reduces the number of nonzero entries in the 3×3 Yukawa submatrices, independent of flux choices. The direction is: loss of very ampleness → appearance of exceptional loci → new selection rules → reduced Yukawa rank.
hypotheses.prediction: Among the 5 D₆-invariant Kähler cone generators, at least 2 will be birationally very ample but not very ample, and the Yukawa couplings involving divisors in these directions will show a rank deficiency: specifically, the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings will decompose such that ≥30% of couplings associated with non-very-ample divisor triples vanish identically (zero intersection number or cohomology obstruction), compared to <10% vanishing rate for triples involving only very ample divisors.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If all 5 D₆-invariant Kähler cone generators are very ample (no birational-but-not-very-ample cases exist), OR if the vanishing rate of Yukawa couplings is statistically indistinguishable (within 10% relative difference) between very-ample and non-very-ample divisor triples, then the proposed causal mechanism is refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: ≥3-fold difference in Yukawa vanishing rate between very-ample and non-very-ample divisor classes (i.e., ≥30% vs ≤10%), corresponding to Cohen's h > 0.5 for proportion comparison

experiment.approach: Computationally classify the ampleness hierarchy of all divisor classes on the GL=12 polytope using CyTools intersection data, then correlate with Yukawa coupling structure under D₆ representation decomposition.
steps: Extract the GL=12 polytope (h¹¹=17, h²¹=20) from CyTools database and compute all 14 prime toric divisor classes with their intersection numbers D³, D²·Dⱼ, D·Dⱼ·Dₖ
Identify the D₆ group action on divisors by computing the polytope automorphism group and its induced action on the divisor lattice; partition divisors into D₆ orbits
For each of the 5 D₆-invariant effective divisor classes, apply Nakai-Moishezon criterion: check D³>0, D²·C>0 for all curve classes C in Mori cone, D·S>0 for all surface classes S

For divisors passing Nakai-Moishezon (ample), compute H¹(X, 𝒪(D)) via Batyrev-Borisov spectral sequence or CyTools cohomology routines; vanishing implies global generation → very ample for CY threefolds
For divisors failing very ampleness, compute base locus Bs(|D|) via linear system analysis; determine whether φ_D is birational by checking degree of image
For birationally-very-ample-but-not-very-ample divisors, identify exceptional locus E and compute its D₆ transformation properties (fixed points, stabilizer subgroups)
Enumerate the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings W_{ijk} = D_i·D_j·D_k and classify each by whether (i,j,k) involves only very-ample divisors, mixed, or only non-very-ample
Compute vanishing statistics: for each category, count couplings with W_{ijk}=0 vs W_{ijk}≠0; perform Fisher exact test comparing vanishing rates
Cross-validate by computing cohomology H^q(X, Ω^p ⊗ 𝒪(D)) for matter field wavefunctions and checking whether exceptional loci contribute to selection rules
experiment.estimated_effort: 2-3 weeks compute + analysis
experiment.data_requirements: CyTools database access for GL=12 polytope; all data is publicly available in Kreuzer-Skarke list and CyTools package
experiment.expected_positive: ≥2 of 5 D₆-invariant divisors are birationally very ample but not very ample, AND Yukawa couplings involving these divisors show ≥30% vanishing rate compared to ≤10% for very-ample-only triples, with Fisher exact test p<0.05
experiment.expected_negative: All 5 invariant divisors are very ample, OR vanishing rates differ by <10% (Fisher p>0.2), indicating ampleness hierarchy does not causally affect Yukawa structure
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The very ampleness status of D₆-invariant divisors has no effect on Yukawa coupling vanishing rates; any observed correlation is due to chance (vanishing rate difference = 0).
experiment.statistical_test: Fisher exact test for 2×2 contingency table (very-ample vs non-very-ample × vanishing vs non-vanishing), two-sided, alpha=0.05; additionally, proportion z-test with continuity correction
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: With 26 total couplings, assuming ~13 in each ampleness category and 80% power at alpha=0.05, we can detect a difference of 30% vs 10% vanishing rates (effect size h≈0.5). If categories are unequal (e.g., 8 vs 18), power remains >70% for 35% vs 10% difference.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size is fixed by geometry (26 invariant Yukawas, 5 invariant divisors). Power analysis: for N₁=N₂=13, detecting 30% vs 10% vanishing (h=0.52) requires N≈25 per group at 80% power; we are near this threshold. If fewer than 10 couplings per category, we will report exact confidence intervals rather than p-values.
limitations: CyTools cohomology computations may fail for non-favorable triangulations; we will use multiple triangulations and report consistency
The 26 invariant couplings are not independent—they share divisors—so effective degrees of freedom may be lower than nominal count
We cannot directly observe twisted-sector wavefunctions computationally; we infer selection rules from intersection numbers
Non-perturbative instanton corrections (E3 on dP divisors) are not included in this tree-level analysis
experiment.requires_followup: Full confirmation requires computing instanton contributions from E3-branes wrapping the 3 del Pezzo divisors to check whether non-perturbative effects restore vanishing Yukawas; this is a separate string amplitude calculation beyond current scope

hypotheses.source_question: Can discrete symmetry groups arising from Calabi-Yau compactifications (specifically D₆ from GL=12 polytopes) constrain or select viable modified gravity theories in the low-energy effective action, and conversely, do modified gravity corrections to the string effective action break or preserve these discrete symmetries?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the D₆ discrete symmetry of the GL=12 Calabi-Yau polytope, when preserved through LVS moduli stabilization, constrains the α' corrections to the 4D effective action such that the resulting scalar-tensor gravity sector has a Brans-Dicke parameter ω_BD restricted to the range ω_BD > 10⁴ (solar system compatible) if and only if the D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling ratios satisfy |κ₂₆₃/κ₃₅₁| < 0.3, establishing a falsifiable correlation between flavor texture and gravitational phenomenology.
hypotheses.mechanism: The 5 D₆-invariant Kähler moduli τ₁…τ₅ enter both the Yukawa superpotential W_{ijk} and the Kähler potential K = -2ln(V) where V = V(τᵢ). LVS stabilization generates α' corrections of the form δK ~ ξ/(g_s^{3/2} V) that produce a scalar-tensor effective action with the volume modulus as the scalar partner to gravity. The D₆ invariance constrains the ratios of Yukawa couplings κᵢⱼₖ via Clebsch-Gordan coefficients, and simultaneously restricts the functional form of V(τᵢ), thereby correlating Yukawa ratios with the effective Brans-Dicke parameter ω_BD ~ V²/|∂V/∂τ|². The causal direction is: D₆ symmetry → constrained moduli space → correlated Yukawa and gravitational parameters.
hypotheses.prediction: For the GL=12 polytope with D₆ preserved after LVS stabilization, the ratio of two specific D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings (κ₂₆₃/κ₃₅₁, corresponding to two distinct D₆ singlet contractions) will be anti-correlated with log₁₀(ω_BD) with Pearson |r| > 0.6 across the viable moduli parameter space. Specifically, Yukawa ratio < 0.3 implies ω_BD > 10⁴, while Yukawa ratio > 0.5 implies ω_BD < 10³.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: The hypothesis is refuted if, across the scanned D₆-invariant LVS-stabilized moduli space of GL=12, either: (1) the Yukawa ratio κ₂₆₃/κ₃₅₁ and log₁₀(ω_BD) show no significant correlation (|r| < 0.3 with p > 0.05), OR (2) parameter points exist where Yukawa ratio < 0.2 yet ω_BD < 10³, demonstrating the two sectors are decoupled despite shared D₆ symmetry.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Pearson |r| > 0.6 between Yukawa ratio and log₁₀(ω_BD), with p < 0.01 over ≥100 sampled parameter points in viable moduli space; AND clear threshold separation: 90% of points with Yukawa ratio < 0.3 must have ω_BD > 10⁴.

experiment.approach: Computationally scan the D₆-invariant Kähler moduli space of the GL=12 polytope under LVS stabilization, computing both D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling ratios and the effective Brans-Dicke parameter from the scalar-tensor reduction of the α'-corrected effective action, then test for predicted correlation.
steps: Use CyTools to extract the GL=12 polytope triangulation, compute the intersection numbers, and identify the 5 D₆-invariant Kähler moduli τ₁…τ₅ and their volume form V(τᵢ).

Implement the LVS scalar potential V_LVS = W₀²/(V³) × [corrections] with α' term δK = -ξ χ(X)/(2 g_s^{3/2} V) and compute stable minima across parameter space (W₀, g_s, ξ in phenomenologically viable ranges).
For each stabilized vacuum, compute the effective 4D scalar-tensor action by dimensional reduction and extract ω_BD from the kinetic mixing between the volume modulus and the 4D graviton.
Compute the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings W_{ijk} = ∫_X Ω ∧ ψᵢ ∧ ψⱼ ∧ ψₖ using the CyTools intersection/cohomology routines, identifying κ₂₆₃ and κ₃₅₁ from the D₆ representation decomposition.
Generate ≥200 parameter points spanning the viable moduli space (τ_Swiss > 5, Kähler cone conditions satisfied, V > 10³ for LVS validity).
Compute Pearson correlation between log₁₀(ω_BD) and Yukawa ratio κ₂₆₃/κ₃₅₁ with bootstrap confidence intervals.
Test threshold prediction: bin by Yukawa ratio (<0.3, 0.3-0.5, >0.5) and compare ω_BD distributions using Kolmogorov-Smirnov test.
Repeat for 2-3 adjacent GL≥8 polytopes with smaller discrete symmetry groups as negative control.
experiment.estimated_effort: 3-4 weeks compute: 1 week for CyTools geometry extraction, 1 week for LVS vacuum scan, 1-2 weeks for Yukawa computation and statistical analysis
experiment.data_requirements: GL=12 polytope specification from Kreuzer-Skarke database (available via CyTools), LVS parameter priors from phenomenological literature (W₀ ~ O(1-100), g_s ~ 0.1-0.3), Cassini bound ω_BD > 4×10⁴ for comparison
experiment.expected_positive: Strong anti-correlation (r < -0.6, p < 0.01) between Yukawa ratio and log₁₀(ω_BD), with clean threshold separation matching prediction. Control polytopes with smaller symmetry groups show weaker or no correlation.
experiment.expected_negative: No significant correlation (|r| < 0.3) across parameter space, OR presence of parameter points violating the predicted threshold mapping (Yukawa ratio < 0.2 with ω_BD < 10³), indicating D₆ symmetry does not couple flavor and gravitational sectors as hypothesized.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The D₆-invariant Yukawa coupling ratio κ₂₆₃/κ₃₅₁ and the Brans-Dicke parameter ω_BD are statistically independent across the LVS-stabilized moduli space of the GL=12 polytope (Pearson r = 0).
experiment.statistical_test: Two-tailed Pearson correlation test with α = 0.01, bootstrap resampling (10,000 iterations) for confidence intervals; Kolmogorov-Smirnov test for threshold bin comparison with α = 0.05; minimum n = 100 parameter points for primary analysis, n = 200 for full scan.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: |r| > 0.3 detectable at 80% power with n = 100 (α = 0.01); target |r| > 0.6 requires n ≈ 50 at 90% power, well within planned sample size
experiment.statistical_power_notes: For |r| = 0.6 effect size, α = 0.01, power = 0.90, required n ≈ 48. We plan n = 200 to detect smaller correlations (|r| ≈ 0.25 detectable at 80% power) and enable robust subgroup analysis. Convergence criterion for LVS minimization: |ΔV/V| < 10⁻⁶ between iterations.
limitations: Yukawa coupling computation assumes topological formula; instanton corrections from del Pezzo divisors not included in initial scan.
LVS approximation valid only for V >> 1; boundary effects near Kähler cone walls may introduce artifacts.
ω_BD extraction assumes single-modulus dominance in gravitational sector; multi-field effects may complicate interpretation.
Specific Yukawa index labeling (κ₂₆₃, κ₃₅₁) requires D₆ representation assignment that may have discrete ambiguities.
experiment.requires_followup: Full confirmation would require computing E3-instanton corrections to Yukawa couplings from del Pezzo divisors (computational but significantly more intensive), and eventual comparison to observed quark/lepton mass ratios to test phenomenological viability of the D₆ flavor assignment.

hypotheses.source_question: Can normal-boundary intersection algorithms be adapted to systematically explore the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant Kähler moduli space of the GL=12 polytope, finding Pareto-optimal configurations that simultaneously satisfy LVS volume stabilization, Yukawa texture constraints, and anomaly cancellation requirements?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the normal-boundary intersection (NBI) algorithm applied to the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant Kähler moduli space of the GL=12 polytope will identify a non-empty Pareto front of configurations simultaneously satisfying LVS viability (τ_Swiss > 5), Yukawa χ² < 100 against observed fermion masses, and proton lifetime bounds (τ_p > 10³⁴ years), whereas random sampling of equivalent computational cost will fail to find any such configurations.
hypotheses.mechanism: NBI constructs uniformly-distributed Pareto-optimal points by solving constrained subproblems along normal directions to the convex hull of individual objective minima. This geometric approach systematically explores the trade-off surface, whereas random sampling wastes resources in dominated regions. In the 5D D₆-invariant moduli space, the intersection structure constraining Yukawa couplings and the LVS volume conditions define competing objectives whose Pareto front topology is unknown—NBI will reveal whether viable phenomenology occupies a finite-measure region or is measure-zero (indicating fundamental incompatibility).
hypotheses.prediction: NBI with 500 subproblem evaluations will identify ≥10 distinct Pareto-optimal points satisfying all three primary constraints (τ_Swiss > 5, Yukawa χ² < 100, proton lifetime > 10³⁴ years), while random sampling with 5000 evaluations (10× more) will find ≤2 such points, demonstrating ≥5× efficiency gain in identifying viable phenomenological configurations.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If random sampling with 5000 evaluations identifies more viable configurations than NBI with 500 evaluations, OR if NBI fails to find any configurations satisfying all three constraints despite successfully constructing a well-resolved Pareto front (indicating the viable region is genuinely empty rather than missed by sampling), this hypothesis is refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: NBI must find ≥5× more viable configurations per evaluation than random sampling, i.e., (N_viable_NBI / 500) > 5 × (N_viable_random / 5000), which simplifies to N_viable_NBI > N_viable_random when NBI uses 10× fewer evaluations.

experiment.approach: Implement NBI algorithm for the GL=12 D₆-invariant Kähler cone using CyTools for objective evaluation, then benchmark against stratified random sampling to compare efficiency in finding phenomenologically viable configurations.
steps: Extract the 5 D₆-invariant Kähler moduli (τ₁...τ₅) from the GL=12 polytope using CyTools, identifying the invariant cone boundaries from the full 17-dimensional Kähler cone.

Implement objective functions: f₁ = -τ_Swiss (from CyTools volume calculation), f₂ = Yukawa χ² (computed from the 26 invariant couplings via intersection numbers against CKM/PMNS experimental values), f₃ = -log₁₀(proton lifetime/years) from dimension-6 operator coefficients.
Find individual minima for each objective via gradient descent in the 5D invariant space; construct the convex hull of these anchor points.

Implement NBI: generate N_subproblems = 500 evenly-spaced points on the convex hull boundary, solve each subproblem (minimize distance to hull along normal direction subject to moduli space constraints).
For each NBI solution, evaluate all three objectives and record whether it satisfies viability thresholds (τ_Swiss > 5, χ² < 100, τ_p > 10³⁴ years).
Run comparative baseline: stratified random sampling with 5000 points in the 5D invariant cone, evaluate same objectives and count viable configurations.
Compute hypervolume indicator for both Pareto approximations; test whether NBI achieves higher hypervolume with fewer evaluations.
Characterize Pareto front topology: compute dimensionality via local PCA, identify ridge structures corresponding to objective trade-offs.
experiment.estimated_effort: 2-3 weeks compute development + 1 week analysis; each NBI subproblem ~10 seconds on single core, full run ~2 hours on 8-core workstation
experiment.data_requirements: GL=12 polytope data from CyTools/Kreuzer-Skarke database; experimental CKM matrix elements and quark masses from PDG; intersection number computation requires CyTools triangulation (pre-computed, ~50MB).
experiment.expected_positive: NBI identifies ≥10 viable configurations with 500 evaluations while random sampling finds ≤2 with 5000 evaluations; Pareto front has well-defined 2D or 3D structure with identifiable trade-off ridges; hypervolume ratio (NBI/random) > 1.5.
experiment.expected_negative: Random sampling outperforms NBI, OR NBI constructs valid Pareto front but the viable region (all constraints satisfied) is provably empty, indicating fundamental incompatibility of LVS + Yukawa + proton decay requirements in this geometry.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The efficiency of finding viable phenomenological configurations in the D₆-invariant moduli space is independent of the sampling strategy; NBI provides no advantage over random sampling in the ratio of viable configurations found per objective evaluation.
experiment.statistical_test: One-sided binomial test comparing proportion of viable configurations: p_NBI = N_viable_NBI/500 vs p_random = N_viable_random/5000; reject H₀ if p_NBI > 5×p_random at α = 0.05. Secondary: Mann-Whitney U test on hypervolume contributions per evaluation.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: With 500 NBI and 5000 random evaluations, assuming base rate p_random = 0.001 (5 viable from random), we can detect p_NBI > 0.02 (10 viable from NBI) at 80% power, corresponding to 4× relative efficiency.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: For rare-event detection (viable configurations expected ~0.1-1% of space), Poisson approximation applies. With λ_random = 5 expected viable points from 5000 samples, detecting λ_NBI ≥ 10 from 500 samples represents 20× rate increase. At α=0.05, power exceeds 90% for this effect size. If true viable rate is higher, power increases correspondingly.
limitations: Yukawa χ² depends on unknown O(1) Kähler metric factors; we use intersection number proxies which may differ from physical couplings by factors of 2-5.
Proton decay calculation assumes specific GUT embedding (SU(5)); other embeddings may shift constraints.
NBI assumes smooth objective landscapes; singular loci in moduli space may cause subproblem failures.
D₆ symmetry preservation under flux stabilization not checked; some 'viable' points may be destabilized.
Comparison is algorithm-to-algorithm; more sophisticated methods (Bayesian optimization, genetic algorithms) not benchmarked.
experiment.requires_followup: Full phenomenological viability requires F-theory flux computation to verify D₆ preservation under stabilization, and explicit instanton calculation for dP divisor corrections—both require extended CyTools/cohomCalg workflows beyond this initial optimization study.

hypotheses.source_question: How does the Green-Schwarz cancellation mechanism for anomalous U(1) symmetries in heterotic string compactifications on Calabi-Yau threefolds with discrete symmetry groups (specifically D₆) constrain or determine the effective anomalous U(1) gauge structure in the low-energy F-theory dual, and vice versa?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the Green-Schwarz anomaly cancellation mechanism in heterotic string compactifications on the GL=12 Calabi-Yau threefold with D₆ symmetry produces exactly one anomalous U(1) that maps under heterotic/F-theory duality to a massless U(1)_{B-L} in the F-theory spectral cover construction, with the D₆-invariant 2-cycle structure determining both the Stückelberg mass hierarchy and the survival of U(1)_{B-L} charges consistent with proton decay suppression.
hypotheses.mechanism: The Green-Schwarz mechanism in the heterotic frame cancels mixed anomalies via axion-gauge couplings determined by the intersection numbers of the 17 Kähler divisors. Under heterotic/F-theory duality, the D₆-invariant 5-dimensional subspace of Kähler moduli maps to a specific G₄-flux configuration on the dual CY4 elliptic fibration. The key causal claim is: D₆ invariance of the 2-cycle basis forces a unique factorization of the anomaly polynomial such that exactly one U(1) combination (identifiable as B-L) remains massless after the Stückelberg mechanism acts, while other anomalous U(1)s acquire masses proportional to D₆-breaking flux components.
hypotheses.prediction: Computing the anomaly polynomial coefficients in both heterotic (via Chern-Simons terms on 17 divisors) and F-theory (via G₄ flux on the dual CY4) frames will yield identical values for the single massless U(1) coupling, with the heterotic Green-Schwarz coefficient b_{GS} matching the F-theory flux quantum N_flux to within 1% numerical precision. Furthermore, the ratio of Stückelberg masses for the 4 massive anomalous U(1)s to the compactification scale will be bounded by m_U(1)/M_s ∈ [0.1, 0.5], with the surviving massless U(1) having B-L charge assignments ±1 on the three D₆-invariant matter curves.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: The hypothesis is refuted if: (1) the D₆-invariant Kähler subspace produces zero or more than one massless U(1) after Green-Schwarz mechanism in either frame, OR (2) the anomaly coefficients computed in heterotic vs F-theory frames differ by more than 10% for any U(1) factor, OR (3) the unique massless U(1) has charge assignments on the three families that are incompatible with B-L (i.e., not ±1 or charges that differ between generations breaking flavor universality required for proton decay suppression).
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Anomaly coefficient matching: |b_{GS}^{het} - N_{flux}^{F}|/b_{GS}^{het} < 0.01; Stückelberg mass ratio for massive U(1)s: 0.1 < m/M_s < 0.5; B-L charge quantization: Q_{B-L} = ±1 exactly on all three families

experiment.approach: Compute the anomaly polynomial and Green-Schwarz counterterms for the GL=12 polytope in both heterotic and F-theory frames using CyTools for geometric data extraction and explicit Chern class computations, then map the D₆-invariant sector through the duality.
steps: Extract the GL=12 polytope from CyTools and compute all 17 divisor classes, their intersection numbers, and the D₆ group action on divisors to identify the 5-dimensional invariant subspace
Compute the second Chern class c₂(TM) and its decomposition on the divisor basis; derive the heterotic anomaly polynomial A₆ = Tr(F³) - Tr(R²)F using the 17-dimensional Kähler cone data
Identify anomalous U(1) factors from the condition ∫_D c₂ ≠ 0 for each divisor D; compute Green-Schwarz coefficients b_{GS,i} = ∫_{CY3} c₂ ∧ ω_i for the 5 D₆-invariant (1,1)-forms
Construct the F-theory dual: identify the elliptic fibration structure of GL=12 using CyTools fibration finder; compute the CY4 as elliptic fibration over the base B₃
Compute G₄ flux quantization on the F-theory CY4: enumerate vertical and horizontal flux components; identify D₆-invariant flux configurations compatible with chirality χ = ±6
Calculate Stückelberg masses for each U(1) factor using M²_U(1) ∝ ∫_{CY4} G₄ ∧ ω_U(1) where ω_U(1) is the Poincaré dual 4-form; identify which U(1)s remain massless
For the massless U(1)(s), compute matter curve charges using spectral cover construction and verify B-L assignment Q = ±1 on three family curves
Compare numerical values: compute ratio of heterotic b_{GS} to F-theory N_flux for each invariant cycle; verify matching within 1% tolerance
tools: custom Python scripts for intersection number computation
Mathematica for symbolic anomaly polynomial manipulation
experiment.estimated_effort: 4-6 weeks compute: 1 week for CyTools data extraction and D₆ orbit analysis, 2 weeks for heterotic anomaly polynomial computation, 2-3 weeks for F-theory dual construction and G₄ flux enumeration
experiment.data_requirements: GL=12 polytope from CyTools database (publicly available); triangulation data for h¹¹=17 geometry; explicit divisor intersection matrices; may require ~100 CPU-hours for triangulation enumeration and flux scanning
experiment.expected_positive: Exactly one massless U(1) survives in both frames with matching anomaly coefficients (within 1%); this U(1) has B-L charges ±1 on all three D₆-invariant family curves; the 4 massive U(1)s have Stückelberg masses in the range 0.1-0.5 M_s, confirming duality and proton decay viability
experiment.expected_negative: Zero or multiple massless U(1)s; OR heterotic/F-theory anomaly coefficients differ by >10%; OR the surviving massless U(1) has charges inconsistent with B-L (not ±1 or family-non-universal)
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The D₆ discrete symmetry of the GL=12 polytope does not constrain the number or properties of massless U(1) factors after Green-Schwarz mechanism; equivalently, the heterotic and F-theory anomaly structures are uncorrelated with the polytope automorphism group.
experiment.statistical_test: Numerical precision test: two-sided comparison of anomaly coefficients with tolerance threshold δ = 0.01 (1% relative error); categorical test for number of massless U(1)s (exact count = 1 required); charge quantization test requiring exact integer B-L charges. No statistical sampling—these are deterministic algebraic computations, so we use numerical precision bounds rather than p-values.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Anomaly coefficient precision: Δb/b < 0.01 distinguishable from numerical noise (using arbitrary precision arithmetic in SageMath); massless U(1) count is exact integer; B-L charge deviation |Q - 1| < 10⁻⁶ detectable
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Not applicable in traditional sense—computations are deterministic algebraic operations. Precision is limited by floating-point representation; using exact rational arithmetic in SageMath eliminates this. Convergence criterion: intersection numbers computed to exact integer values; flux quantization verified to satisfy integrality ∫G₄ ∈ ℤ + ½χ(CY4)/24.
limitations: GL=12 polytope may have multiple fine regular star triangulations (FRSTs)—results could depend on triangulation choice; will sample 10 representative triangulations
F-theory dual may not be unique; assumes standard stable degeneration limit which may miss non-perturbative corrections
Spectral cover construction assumes rank-1 Higgs bundle; higher rank could change U(1) counting
B-L identification assumes standard embedding; flux breaking to SM could produce different U(1) combinations
Numerical precision in intersection number computation may require extended precision for h¹¹=17 geometries
experiment.requires_followup: Full phenomenological viability requires explicit computation of D₆-invariant Yukawa textures and comparison to observed quark/lepton masses—this is a separate Stage 4 investigation building on the U(1) structure established here

hypotheses.source_question: Can the Nakayama classification technique for surfaces with bounded singularities be systematically extended to enumerate divisor configurations on Calabi-Yau threefolds with discrete symmetry groups, specifically to classify D₆-invariant divisor classes and their intersection structures?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that Nakayama's divisibility index bounds on singular fibers, when restricted to the D₆-invariant sublattice of H²(X,ℤ) for the GL=12 Calabi-Yau threefold, will predict at least 30% of the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings to be arithmetically forbidden (zero by divisor intersection constraints) independent of complex structure moduli choice.
hypotheses.mechanism: The Nakayama classification technique constrains allowed divisor configurations through index-theoretic bounds on canonical divisor behavior. When the intersection form is restricted to the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant Kähler sublattice, the divisibility conditions impose selection rules on triple intersection numbers ∫_X D_i ∧ D_j ∧ D_k. These constraints propagate to Yukawa couplings W_{ijk} via the Kodaira-Spencer map, forcing certain couplings to vanish when the corresponding divisor products violate Nakayama's singularity bounds on the invariant sublattice.
hypotheses.prediction: At least 8 of the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings (≥30%) will be identified as arithmetically forbidden by Nakayama divisibility constraints on the D₆-invariant intersection lattice, and these predicted zeros will be independent of the 5 D₆-invariant complex structure moduli.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the Nakayama divisibility analysis on the D₆-invariant sublattice produces fewer than 4 arithmetically forbidden Yukawa entries (<15%), OR if entries predicted to be forbidden by this analysis are shown to be generically nonzero through explicit period integral computation on the GL=12 threefold, the hypothesis is refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: ≥8/26 (30%) of D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings classified as arithmetically forbidden, with ≥90% agreement between Nakayama-predicted zeros and independent CyTools triple-intersection verification

experiment.approach: Extract the D₆-invariant sublattice of H²(X,ℤ) from the GL=12 polytope using CyTools, apply Nakayama's divisibility index bounds to classify allowed/forbidden triple intersections, and compare predictions against explicit Yukawa coupling structure.
steps: Use CyTools to extract the full intersection tensor C_{ijk} and divisor basis for the GL=12 polytope (h¹¹=17)
Compute the D₆ group action on divisor classes using the polytope automorphism group; project H²(X,ℤ) onto the 5-dimensional D₆-invariant sublattice L^{D₆}
Compute the restricted intersection form Q_{ab} = C_{ijk} v^i_a v^j_b v^k on the invariant basis vectors {v_a}_{a=1}^5
Apply Nakayama's divisibility bounds: for each invariant divisor class D_a, compute the divisibility index div(D_a) in Pic(X) and check singular fiber constraints
Enumerate which triple products D_a ∧ D_b ∧ D_c violate Nakayama bounds (index exceeds Gorenstein index 12, or violates canonical divisor constraints)
Map the 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings to their corresponding divisor triple products via the Kodaira-Spencer identification
Classify each of the 26 couplings as 'arithmetically forbidden' (violates bounds), 'arithmetically allowed', or 'undetermined'
Verify predictions using CyTools' explicit triple intersection computation on a representative triangulation
Test independence from complex structure moduli by checking whether forbidden entries remain zero across the 5-parameter D₆-invariant complex structure moduli space
tools: Custom Python for intersection tensor manipulation
experiment.estimated_effort: 3-4 weeks compute + analysis
experiment.data_requirements: GL=12 polytope data from CyTools database (h¹¹=17, h²¹=20); D₆ automorphism group generators from polytope symmetry analysis; all 14 divisor class intersection numbers
experiment.expected_positive: ≥8 of 26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings are classified as arithmetically forbidden by Nakayama bounds, verified to be zero in CyTools intersection computation, demonstrating the method's predictive power for Yukawa texture classification
experiment.expected_negative: Fewer than 4 couplings are classified as forbidden, OR predicted-forbidden couplings are found to be generically nonzero in CyTools, indicating Nakayama bounds do not constrain CY3 Yukawa structure in the D₆-invariant sector
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The Nakayama divisibility classification on the D₆-invariant sublattice predicts no more Yukawa zeros than random chance (≤2/26 ≈ 8%), i.e., the method provides no information beyond what CyTools intersection calculus already computes directly
experiment.statistical_test: One-sided binomial test: H₁ that the fraction of Nakayama-predicted forbidden couplings exceeds 15% (≥4/26), with α=0.05. For the 90% agreement criterion: Cohen's κ ≥ 0.8 between Nakayama predictions and CyTools verification on the 26 couplings.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: ≥4/26 (15%) Nakayama-forbidden couplings to reject H₀ at α=0.05; target is ≥8/26 (30%) for strong confirmation
experiment.statistical_power_notes: With n=26 D₆-invariant Yukawa couplings, detecting a 30% forbidden rate against a null of 8% yields power >95% at α=0.05 (exact binomial). The Cohen's κ comparison requires all 26 couplings to be classified by both methods; no sample size ambiguity since the population is exhaustively enumerable.
limitations: Nakayama bounds developed for surfaces may require non-trivial extension to threefold divisor arithmetic
D₆ action on cohomology may not be fully determined by polytope automorphisms (need to verify faithfulness)
Non-perturbative corrections (E3-instantons) can generate couplings forbidden at arithmetic level
Method does not predict the magnitude of allowed couplings, only vanishing constraints
experiment.requires_followup: If successful, requires explicit period integral calculation on GL=12 CY3 to verify that 'allowed' couplings are indeed nonzero at generic complex structure — this involves solving Picard-Fuchs equations for the D₆-invariant moduli sector

hypotheses.source_question: How does the classification of discrete automorphism groups differ between rigid Calabi-Yau threefolds (h²¹=0) and their higher-dimensional moduli counterparts, and what constraints does this impose on flavor symmetry realizations in string compactifications?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that among all reflexive 4-polytopes in the Kreuzer-Skarke database with Euler characteristic |χ|=6, the GL=12 polytope possesses the unique maximal discrete point group (D₆, order 12), and that this maximality correlates with a structurally distinct Hodge number pair (h¹¹, h²¹) that permits exactly 3 D₆-invariant generations under any faithful group action on the matter sector.
hypotheses.mechanism: The discrete automorphism group of a reflexive polytope acts on its face lattice and induces a subgroup of the Calabi-Yau's geometric symmetries. Polytopes with higher Gorenstein index (GL) generically admit larger point groups because their dual polytopes have more symmetric vertex configurations. For |χ|=6 (3-generation phenomenology), the constraint χ = 2(h¹¹ - h²¹) = ±6 restricts the (h¹¹, h²¹) locus; D₆ maximality would imply that no other point on this locus admits a larger crystallographic point group compatible with the reflexivity condition.
hypotheses.prediction: A complete enumeration of point groups for all |χ|=6 reflexive 4-polytopes in the KS database will show that D₆ (order 12) is the unique maximal group, with the next-largest groups having order ≤6, and that the GL=12 polytope is the sole representative achieving this maximum.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: Discovery of any |χ|=6 reflexive 4-polytope in the KS database whose automorphism group has order >12 (e.g., a polytope with S₄, A₄×Z₂, or larger dihedral/cyclic group of order ≥13) would definitively refute the claim of D₆ maximality.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: The GL=12 D₆ polytope must be strictly maximal: all other |χ|=6 polytopes must have |Aut| ≤ 11, with a gap of at least order 2 (i.e., next-largest ≤10) to constitute robust maximality rather than coincidental tie.

experiment.approach: Systematic computational enumeration of discrete automorphism groups for all reflexive 4-polytopes with |χ|=6 in the Kreuzer-Skarke database, using lattice automorphism algorithms and cross-validation with CyTools triangulation data.
steps: Step 1: Query the Kreuzer-Skarke database (≈473 million polytopes) to extract all reflexive 4-polytopes satisfying |χ|=6, using the relation χ = 2(h¹¹ - h²¹) to filter Hodge pairs with h¹¹ - h²¹ = ±3.
Step 2: For each filtered polytope, compute the automorphism group of the face lattice using the SageMath/Normaliz/PALP stack, which implements Schreier-Sims algorithms for lattice automorphisms.
Step 3: Classify each automorphism group up to isomorphism using GAP's SmallGroups library, recording group order, structure description, and whether it contains D₆ as a subgroup.
Step 4: Cross-validate a random 5% sample using CyTools' independent triangulation and symmetry detection to confirm consistency of group orders.
Step 5: Construct the distribution of point group orders across all |χ|=6 polytopes; identify all polytopes achieving the maximum order.
Step 6: For the maximal-order polytope(s), verify the GL index and confirm identification with the known GL=12 polytope via vertex/facet comparison.
Step 7: Compute the invariant subspace dimensions (h¹¹_inv, h²¹_inv) under each maximal group action to test whether exactly 5 invariant Kähler moduli is a unique or generic feature.
experiment.estimated_effort: 2-4 weeks compute time on 100-core cluster (primary bottleneck: automorphism computation for ~10⁴-10⁵ polytopes satisfying |χ|=6 filter)
experiment.data_requirements: Full Kreuzer-Skarke reflexive 4-polytope database (public, ~2TB uncompressed); CyTools installation with triangulation cache for GL≥8 polytopes; GAP SmallGroups library (public, ~500MB)
experiment.expected_positive: D₆ is the unique maximal point group among |χ|=6 polytopes, achieved only by the GL=12 polytope, with all other polytopes having |Aut| ≤ 10. The 5 D₆-invariant Kähler moduli structure is unique or shared by ≤2 other polytopes.
experiment.expected_negative: At least one |χ|=6 polytope has |Aut| > 12, or multiple polytopes achieve |Aut| = 12 with different group structures, indicating D₆ is not uniquely maximal.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The distribution of point group orders among |χ|=6 reflexive 4-polytopes is such that the GL=12 polytope does not achieve a unique maximum; either larger groups exist or multiple polytopes share the maximal order 12.
experiment.statistical_test: Exact enumeration (deterministic); no sampling uncertainty. Confirmation criterion: GL=12 polytope is the sole |χ|=6 polytope with |Aut|=12 AND all others have |Aut| ≤ 10. Chi-squared goodness-of-fit to test whether the observed order distribution differs from random lattice polytope expectations (α=0.01).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Binary outcome: D₆ is strictly maximal (gap ≥2 in group order) or not. Scientifically meaningful if the maximality gap exceeds statistical fluctuations in related Hodge number strata.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Exact enumeration of finite database; power=1.0 for the primary hypothesis. For the secondary correlation analysis (group order vs. Hodge structure), given ~10⁴ expected |χ|=6 polytopes, we have >99% power to detect r>0.05 correlations at α=0.01.
limitations: Automorphism computation is NP-hard in general; may require heuristic cutoffs for highly complex polytopes
Database completeness: KS classification is complete for 4D reflexive polytopes, but the |χ|=6 filter depends on correct Hodge number computation
Point group ≠ full CY automorphism group; fibration structures may admit additional symmetries not visible at polytope level
Does not address whether D₆ acts faithfully on 3 generations—only geometric maximality
experiment.requires_followup: To confirm D₆ acts faithfully as flavor symmetry on 3 SM generations, requires explicit heterotic or F-theory model building on the GL=12 geometry with matter spectrum computation—beyond pure polytope enumeration.

hypotheses.source_question: Are 'fermion mass hierarchy' and 'fermionic mass hierarchy' treated as operationally distinct concepts in the discrete-symmetry flavor literature, and if so, does the terminological fragmentation obscure a unified mechanism derivable from D₆ Calabi-Yau compactifications?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the terminological fragmentation between 'fermion mass hierarchy' and 'fermionic mass hierarchy' in the discrete-symmetry flavor literature reflects genuine methodological divergence: bottom-up papers predominantly target mass eigenvalue ratios while top-down string papers predominantly target Yukawa texture zeros, and this divergence masks a quantifiable overlap where D₆-symmetric Calabi-Yau constructions could simultaneously constrain both observables.
hypotheses.mechanism: The two citation clusters have evolved different success metrics: bottom-up discrete-flavor models (A₄, S₄, Δ(27)) optimize Clebsch-Gordan coefficients to reproduce mass eigenvalue ratios (m_t/m_c, m_c/m_u, etc.), while top-down string constructions optimize Yukawa integral selection rules to produce texture zeros in the 3×3 matrix. Because eigenvalue ratios and texture zeros are related but not equivalent constraints (a texture zero implies eigenvalue relations but not vice versa), the communities cite different benchmark observables. The D₆ symmetry of the GL=12 polytope provides 26 invariant Yukawa couplings whose Clebsch-Gordan structure can be mapped to both observables simultaneously, potentially unifying both approaches.
hypotheses.prediction: A systematic classification of papers in both clusters will show that ≥70% of bottom-up papers cite quark mass ratios (m_t:m_c:m_u) as primary observables while ≥70% of top-down papers cite Yukawa texture zeros as primary observables, with ≤15% of papers in either cluster explicitly computing both. Furthermore, the co-citation overlap between clusters will be ≤10% of total citations, and identifying ≤5 bridging papers will increase semantic similarity between cluster centroids by ≥0.3 (cosine similarity).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If >40% of papers in both clusters explicitly compute both mass eigenvalue ratios AND texture zeros as primary observables, then the claimed methodological divergence does not exist and the terminological fragmentation is purely superficial with no scientific content. Alternatively, if co-citation overlap exceeds 25%, the clusters are not genuinely separated.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Cluster separation: co-citation Jaccard index < 0.10; observable divergence: >55% difference in primary observable type between clusters; bridging effect: ≥0.25 increase in inter-cluster cosine similarity after adding ≤5 papers

experiment.approach: Perform bibliometric and semantic analysis of the discrete-symmetry flavor literature to quantify cluster separation, classify primary observables in each cluster, and identify minimal bridging references that would unify the terminology.
steps: Collect corpus: Query INSPIRE-HEP and arXiv (hep-ph, hep-th) for papers containing ('fermion mass hierarchy' OR 'fermionic mass hierarchy') AND ('discrete symmetry' OR 'flavor symmetry' OR 'Calabi-Yau'), yielding ~200-500 papers from 2000-2024
Build citation network: Extract all citation edges using Semantic Scholar API; construct directed graph G with papers as nodes
Cluster detection: Apply Louvain community detection to identify citation clusters; verify that the two terminological variants fall into distinct communities
Compute co-citation metrics: Calculate Jaccard index and cosine similarity between clusters; record inter-cluster citation fraction

Observable classification: For top-50 papers by citation count in each cluster, manually annotate whether primary observable is (a) mass eigenvalue ratios, (b) Yukawa texture zeros, (c) mixing angles (CKM/PMNS), or (d) multiple. Use two independent annotators with Cohen's κ for inter-rater reliability
Semantic embedding: Embed paper abstracts using SciBERT; compute cluster centroids and inter-cluster cosine similarity
Bridging paper identification: Find papers citing both clusters; rank by bridging centrality; identify minimal set that maximizes inter-cluster similarity increase
D₆ mapping: For papers mentioning dihedral symmetry (D_n, n≥4), extract Yukawa ansätze and map Clebsch-Gordan coefficients to both eigenvalue ratios and texture zeros; quantify how many achieve both
Statistical testing: Bootstrap 95% CI for all metrics; test cluster separation against random relabeling null model
experiment.estimated_effort: 2-3 weeks: 1 week data collection and network construction, 1 week manual annotation (50-100 papers), 0.5-1 week analysis and visualization
experiment.data_requirements: Public bibliometric data from INSPIRE-HEP and Semantic Scholar; no proprietary access required. Manual annotation of ~100 papers for observable classification.
experiment.expected_positive: Co-citation Jaccard index < 0.10 between clusters; >70% of bottom-up cluster papers cite mass ratios as primary observable while >70% of top-down cluster cite texture zeros; identification of ≤5 bridging papers increases inter-cluster cosine similarity by ≥0.25; D₆-mentioning papers show higher dual-observable coverage than non-dihedral papers
experiment.expected_negative: Co-citation Jaccard index > 0.25 (clusters not separated); <55% difference in primary observable distribution between clusters (no methodological divergence); no measurable bridging effect from adding citations (fragmentation is random noise, not structural)
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The terminological variants 'fermion mass hierarchy' and 'fermionic mass hierarchy' occur in a single, well-connected citation cluster with uniform distribution of primary observables, and any apparent fragmentation is indistinguishable from random term variation (Jaccard > 0.20, observable distribution χ² p > 0.05)
experiment.statistical_test: Two-sided χ² test for observable distribution independence between clusters, α=0.05; permutation test (n=10000) for co-citation Jaccard index against random cluster assignment null; paired t-test for semantic similarity change after bridging paper addition, α=0.05, power=0.80
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: With ~100 papers per cluster and 80% power at α=0.05: detectable difference in observable proportions of ≥20 percentage points (χ² test); detectable Jaccard difference of ≥0.08 from random null (permutation test); detectable similarity increase of ≥0.15 with n=10 bridging candidates (paired t-test)
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Assuming ~200-500 papers total split ~50/50 between clusters, the χ² test for 2×4 contingency table (cluster × observable type) has >90% power to detect 25-point differences in primary observable proportions. Permutation test with 10,000 resamples provides exact p-values. For bridging analysis, effect size (Cohen's d) of 1.0 expected based on prior bibliometric unification studies; n=10 bridging candidates gives 80% power at α=0.05.
limitations: Manual annotation introduces subjectivity despite inter-rater calibration
Corpus limited to English-language papers indexed in INSPIRE/arXiv
Semantic embedding captures abstract-level features, not full-text methodology differences
Citation networks reflect sociological factors (prestige, language barriers) beyond scientific content
D₆-specific analysis may have small sample size if few papers explicitly use dihedral symmetry
experiment.requires_followup: If bibliometric analysis confirms structural divergence, a follow-up theoretical study would explicitly compute Yukawa integrals for the GL=12 D₆ polytope and derive both mass eigenvalue ratios AND texture zero predictions from the same Clebsch-Gordan decomposition—demonstrating that the D₆ geometry genuinely unifies both observables, not just the literature.

hypotheses.source_question: Can discrete symmetry groups arising from Calabi-Yau compactifications (specifically D₆ from GL=12 polytopes) provide a mathematical framework for optimizing distributed energy flow scheduling in smart building networks, analogous to how D₆ constrains Yukawa coupling textures?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that imposing D₆-equivariant constraints on the state-action space of a model-predictive controller (MPC) for multi-zone building energy management will reduce computational solve time by at least 50% while maintaining energy cost performance within 5% of unconstrained MPC, because the symmetry quotient reduces the effective optimization dimension from n to n/|D₆| = n/12 for buildings with hexagonal or 6-fold periodic thermal zone topology.
hypotheses.mechanism: D₆ symmetry acts on the energy flow graph G = (V, E) where V are thermal zones and E are HVAC energy transfers. When G admits a D₆ automorphism (e.g., 6 zones arranged hexagonally with 2-fold reflection), the MPC state vector x ∈ ℝⁿ decomposes into D₆-irreducible representations: x = x₁ ⊕ x₂ ⊕ ... where each xᵢ transforms under a D₆ irrep. The optimal control u* must also be D₆-equivariant (since the cost function and dynamics are symmetric), so u* lies in the D₆-invariant subspace of dimension n/12. This reduces the quadratic program from O(n³) to O((n/12)³) ≈ 0.05% of original complexity, with constraint matrices block-diagonalizing under the irrep decomposition.
hypotheses.prediction: For a 12-zone building with exact D₆ symmetry, the D₆-equivariant MPC will solve in ≤50% of the wall-clock time of standard MPC (averaged over 1000 random initial conditions), while the total energy cost over a 24-hour horizon differs by ≤5% from the unconstrained optimum.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the D₆-equivariant MPC requires ≥80% of the solve time of unconstrained MPC on D₆-symmetric building topologies, OR if the energy cost exceeds the unconstrained optimum by >15%, the dimension-reduction mechanism fails to deliver practical computational advantage and the hypothesis is refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Solve time reduction ≥50% (speedup factor ≥2×); energy cost deviation ≤5% from unconstrained optimum; demonstrated on at least 3 distinct D₆-symmetric building topologies with n ≥ 12 zones.

experiment.approach: Construct synthetic building energy models with exact D₆ symmetry, implement equivariant MPC via irrep decomposition, and benchmark against standard MPC on solve time and solution quality.
steps: Define a 12-zone thermal network graph G with D₆ automorphism group (6 zones in hexagonal arrangement + 6 mirrored zones, or 12-gon topology with 6-fold rotation and reflection symmetry).

Implement linear thermal dynamics: ẋ = Ax + Bu + Dw where A, B, D are D₆-equivariant matrices (block-circulant + reflection structure). Use EnergyPlus zone model parameters for realistic thermal capacitances and conductances.
Compute the D₆ irrep decomposition of ℝ¹² using character table: D₆ has 6 irreps (four 1D, two 2D). Construct the unitary change-of-basis matrix U that block-diagonalizes A.
Formulate standard MPC: minimize ∑ₜ (xₜᵀQxₜ + uₜᵀRuₜ) subject to dynamics, box constraints on u (HVAC capacity), and comfort bounds on x (temperature). Implement in CVXPY with OSQP solver.

Formulate D₆-equivariant MPC: transform to irrep coordinates x̃ = Ux, solve the block-diagonal QP (6 independent smaller QPs), transform back. Verify that constraints are preserved under the symmetry.

Generate 1000 random initial conditions x₀ drawn uniformly from the feasible region, and 1000 random disturbance sequences w_t (weather/occupancy). Run both controllers over 24-hour horizon (96 steps at 15-min intervals).
Record solve time per MPC step (wall-clock, averaged over 10 runs per instance), total energy cost ∑ ||u_t||, and constraint violations. Compute speedup ratio and cost deviation.
Repeat for 3 building topologies: (a) ideal 12-zone hexagon, (b) 18-zone with D₆ × Z₃ symmetry, (c) 12-zone with approximate D₆ (5% parameter perturbation breaking exact symmetry).
Statistical analysis: paired t-test on solve times, 95% CI on cost deviation, report effect sizes (Cohen's d for speedup).
tools: GAP or SageMath for D₆ character table verification
experiment.estimated_effort: 2-3 weeks compute + implementation; single-machine feasible (1000 QP solves × 96 steps × 2 methods ≈ 200k solves, each <1s)
experiment.data_requirements: DOE commercial reference building thermal parameters (publicly available); no real building data required for primary test. Weather data from TMY3 files (free from NREL).
experiment.expected_positive: D₆-MPC solves in ≤50% time of standard MPC (speedup ≥2×) with energy cost within 5% of optimum across all 1000 test cases and all 3 topologies.
experiment.expected_negative: D₆-MPC achieves <1.25× speedup OR incurs >15% energy cost penalty, indicating that the theoretical dimension reduction does not translate to practical solver speedup (e.g., due to overhead from basis transformation or constraint handling).
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The D₆-equivariant MPC provides no statistically significant reduction in solve time (speedup ≤ 1.0) compared to standard MPC on D₆-symmetric building topologies.
experiment.statistical_test: Paired two-sided t-test on log(solve_time), α = 0.05, power = 0.90. Secondary: equivalence test (TOST) for energy cost within ±5% margin.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Speedup factor ≥ 1.5× (Cohen's d > 0.8 for solve time reduction); with n=1000 paired samples, power > 0.99 for d > 0.3.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: With 1000 paired samples per topology and assumed effect size d = 1.0 (50% solve time reduction on log scale), power exceeds 0.999 at α = 0.05. For the approximate-symmetry case (c), we expect smaller effect (d ≈ 0.5), still yielding power > 0.99.
limitations: Exact D₆ symmetry is idealized; real buildings have parameter heterogeneity that breaks symmetry. The approximate-symmetry test (c) partially addresses this but systematic asymmetry (e.g., solar orientation) is not modeled.
Linear thermal dynamics are a simplification; nonlinear effects (radiative transfer, humidity) may not preserve equivariance.
OSQP solver may not be representative of industrial MPC solvers; speedup ratios may differ for interior-point methods.
The analogy to CY Yukawa constraints is mathematical (dimension reduction via group theory) rather than physical; no claim of deeper connection to string phenomenology.
experiment.requires_followup: Hardware-in-the-loop validation on a real 6-zone HVAC testbed (e.g., FLEXLAB at LBNL) to confirm that symmetry-constrained control performs comparably under real disturbances and actuator nonlinearities. This would require 3-6 month facility access.
